content: How can I help you today?

Honestly, I’m not sure. This is all new to me, and I’m just feeling really overwhelmed lately. My partner convinced me to come, so I guess I’m here to try to figure out why I can’t sleep at night and how to deal with everything going on.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you’ve been carrying a lot lately, and brought yourself here despite feeling overwhelmed. That shows courage. If you’re open to it, we can explore what’s been troubling your sleep and how things in your life might be affecting you. Where would you like to begin?

I guess my job is the main thing. Things are so stressful at work, and I feel like I’m constantly on edge. I’m worried about being fired, and with two kids and bills to pay, it’s hard to think about anything else. It’s just...a lot.

That sounds incredibly tough to be under so much pressure, especially while worrying about your family and job security. Balancing those responsibilities can feel overwhelming, especially when it starts affecting your sleep. How have you been coping with the stress so far?

I’m not really sure I’ve been coping much. I just lie awake at night thinking about everything, and during the day I try to push through, but it feels like I’m running on fumes. I don’t really know how to make things better.

It sounds like you’ve been trying to keep going despite feeling physically exhausted and mentally drained. That takes strength, even though it feels like you're just running on fumes. Given how much is on your mind at night and during the day, how does it feel to talk about it now?

It feels a bit weird, to be honest. I’m not used to talking about this kind of stuff with anyone, and part of me wonders if it’s even going to help. But I guess it’s nice to at least say it out loud instead of just keeping it in my head.

It's understandable to feel unsure, especially if sharing like this is new for you. But acknowledging what’s been weighing on you can be an important first step. It's good that you're giving yourself the chance to let some of it out today. What would you say is the hardest thing about keeping it all inside?

I guess the hardest part is feeling like I don’t have anyone to really talk to about it. I don’t want to burden my partner with all my worries, and at work, I feel like I have to act like everything is fine. It’s just exhausting keeping it all bottled up.

It takes a lot of energy to hold everything in and feel like you have to manage it on your own. Not wanting to burden your partner shows how much you care about them, but it can leave you feeling isolated when you're struggling. Now that you’ve shared some of this, how does it feel to imagine finding ways to let some of that weight off your shoulders?

To be honest, it’s hard to imagine right now. I’ve been so used to carrying it all by myself that I don’t really know what it would look like to not feel this way. But I know I can’t keep going like this forever, so I’m open to figuring out what might help.

Being open to exploring ways to feel better is such an important step, even when imagining change feels difficult right now. You’ve acknowledged that you can't keep carrying this alone, and that’s a powerful insight. What do you think might be the first step toward easing even a small part of what you’re carrying?

I’m really not sure. Maybe trying to talk about things more, like I’m doing here, or finding some way to stop my brain from spiraling at night? It feels like everything’s so tangled up that I don’t even know where to begin, but I’m willing to try something if it might help.

It sounds like you're beginning to think about letting yourself talk things through more and finding ways to calm your thoughts at night. Even though things feel tangled up right now, being willing to explore these ideas is an important step forward. Is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to talk through before we look at what might help with these first steps?

It’s a bit tough to pinpoint just one thing because everything feels so connected—work stress, sleep problems, and worrying about my family. I guess one more thing I keep thinking about is how I’ll feel if I really do lose my job. I’m scared I won’t be able to provide for my family, and I don’t want to let them down. It’s hard to shake that feeling.

It’s clear how deeply you care about your family and your role in supporting them—that fear of letting them down shows how much they mean to you. Facing those "what if" thoughts about losing your job can be overwhelming, and it’s no wonder they’re keeping you up at night. Would it help to unpack those fears a little more or explore what’s within your control right now?
Take your time—there’s no rush here. When you’re ready, we can talk more about what you’re going through and what steps might help you move forward.
Take your time—there’s no rush here. When you’re ready, we can keep exploring what’s weighing on you and how to make things feel a little more manageable.

It’s completely okay to have moments of pause, especially when thinking about everything that’s on your mind. How about we start with something small—what could bring just a bit more ease into your day or night?
